options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. Bilirubin is a cyclic tetrapyrrole.

questions.text: Select the one of the following statements that is NOT CORRECT:

options.label: A
options.text: Wilson disease can be treated using copper chelators such as penicillamine.

options.label: B
options.text: Wilson disease is characterized by copper toxicosis (abnormally high levels of copper).

questions.correct_answer: C. Wilson disease is caused by mutation in the gene encoding ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the step in glycolysis catalyzed by hexokinase and in gluconeogenesis by glucose 6-phosphotase is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hexokinase has a low Km its activity in liver increases as the concentration of glucose in the portal blood increases.

options.label: B
options.text: Glucose 6-phosphatase is mainly active in muscle in the fasting state.

options.label: C
options.text: In hexokinase and glucose 6-phosphotase are both equally active at the same time there is net formation of ATP from ADP and phosphate.

options.label: D
options.text: Liver contains an isoenzyme of hexokinase, glucokinase, which is especially important in the fed state.

questions.correct_answer: D. Liver contains an isoenzyme of hexokinase, glucokinase, which is especially important in the fed state.

options.label: A

questions.correct_answer: B. A posterior tympanotomy provides access to the mesotympanum and hypotympanum by dissection of the facial recess.

A 20-years-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her family after they were unable to get her to eat or drink anything for the past 2 days. The patient, although awake, is completely unresponsive both vocally and nonverbally. She actively resists any attempt to be moved. Her family states that for the previous 7 months she has become increasingly withdrawn, socially isolated, and bizarre, often speaking to people no one else could see. Which of the following diagnosis is the most likely in this patient?

A 35-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin for the past several months. Examination reveals pallor and mild tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.0 g/dL Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV): 70 fL Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC): 400 µg/dL Transferrin Saturation: 7% Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

45-year-old woman presents to her physician with complaints of swollen, bleeding gums. She also reports easy bruising and multiple pinpoint hemorrhages on her lower extremities. Laboratory results are as follows:Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL,Platelet count: 120,000/mm³,Bleeding time is prolonged and activated Partial Thromboplastin Time- 32 seconds (normal range: 25-35 seconds).Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man presents with a one-month history of hematuria, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine levels. He reports recurrent sinusitis and has a history of longstanding rheumatoid arthritis treated with NSAIDs.Laboratory results reveal the following: Urinalysis: dysmorphic RBCs with RBC casts. Serum creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL ANCA (Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) test: Positive for c-ANCA (cytoplasmic pattern) Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

30-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine for the past two weeks. Physical examination reveals icteric sclera and hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows: Total Bilirubin: 4.5 mg/dL ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase): 400 U/L HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Positive Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative Which of the following best describes the patient's hepatitis B infection status?

A 60-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, the patient is hemodynamically stable with a regular pulse.ECG done is shown in the figure. Which of the following best describes the rhythm observed on the ECG?

A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with chest pain of 6 hours duration. The ECG shows ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V1-V4, troponin levels are elevated. The patient is hemodynamically stable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of antiplatelet therapy and enoxaparin

questions.correct_answer: C. Administration of antiplatelet therapy and enoxaparin

questions.text: A 50-year-old male comes for a routine check-up. His blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. There is no other comorbid condition. Laboratory tests, including renal function and electrolytes, ECG and ECHO are within normal limits. Repeat BP after one weeks is similar. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate lifestyle modifications and reassess blood pressure in 3 months.

options.label: B
options.text: Start antihypertensive medication single agent immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: Start antihypertensive medication dual agents immediately

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring.

questions.correct_answer: A. Initiate lifestyle modifications and reassess blood pressure in 3 months.

On examination, the affected joint is warm, erythematous, and tender. Laboratory studies show normal serum uric acid level. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the initial treatment?

questions.correct_answer: D. Gout; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or colchicine

Laboratory studies reveal an elevated creatine kinase level.What is the most likely diagnosis

Arterial blood gas analysis of a patient admitted in ICU reveals a pH of 7.25, PaCO2 of 60 mm Hg, HCO3- of 30 mEq/L, and PaO2 of 60 mm Hg on room air. The patient's respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute. What acid-base disorder is present, and what is the likely underlying mechanism?

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory alkalosis; Hyperventilation due to anxiety

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis; Lactic acidosis due to sepsis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the cardiology clinic with worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and pedal edema. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, and peripheral edema. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 25%. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic treatment for this patient?

A 35-year-old HIV-positive male with a CD4 count of 50 cells/μL presents to the hospital with a two-week history of progressively worsening headache, fever, and altered mental status. On physical examination, he is noted to have neck rigidity. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals an elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and a positive India ink stain. What is the likely diagnosis?

45-year-old female presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and morning stiffness involving multiple joints, including the small joints of the hands and wrists. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling in the affected joints. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is a characteristic feature of this condition?

A 30-year-old woman with a known history of type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and confusion. On examination, she is tachycardic and hypotensive. Laboratory studies reveal blood glucose of 450 mg/dL, ketonuria, arterial pH of 7.20, and serum bicarbonate of 10 mEq/L. What is the immediate treatment?

A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his face and body. On examination, he has right hemiparesis and right facial droop. The weakness is more pronounced in the lower half of the face, sparing the forehead. Which artery is involved?

A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent headaches. She describes the pain as a constant, bilateral pressure or tightness sensation that is not pulsating. The headaches are not associated with nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light and sound. The patient notes that the headaches often occur during periods of stress. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is a common characteristic of this type of headache?

A 55-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of bilateral lower extremity numbness, tingling, and burning sensations. Physical examination reveals diminished vibratory sensation and absent ankle reflexes. What is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for diabetic neuropathy, and what is the mechanism of action of this medication?

options.label: B
options.text: Gabapentin; Modulation of voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.correct_answer: B. Gabapentin; Modulation of voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with bone pain, fatigue, and recurrent infections. Laboratory studies reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal insufficiency. Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of a monoclonal spike (M-spike). What is the primary treatment modality of this condition?

A 45-year-old farmer presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fever, sweats, fatigue, and joint pain. He reports having direct contact with farm animals, particularly goats, on his rural property. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 101.5°F (38.6°C) and demonstrates tenderness in multiple joints, especially in the knees. Laboratory studies reveal anemia, leukopenia, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The patient mentions a previous episode of undulant fever several years ago but did not seek medical attention at that time. What is the likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 70-year-old woman presented to her primary care physician with the onset of diabetes mellitus, unintentional weight loss, anemia, and diarrhea. Shortly thereafter, glossitis developed, along with a widespread pruritic rash that was recalcitrant to treatment with systemic and topical steroids. At the time of her referral to a dermatologist, her trunk and extremities were covered with gyrate, dusky tan-pink and bright pink-red plaques with exfoliative, hemorrhagic, and varnish like scales; these did not affect the perianal area, hands, or feet. Skin biopsy revealed broad zones of confluent parakeratosis, an edematous dermis with a mixed infiltrate of lymphocytes, histiocytes, and occasional eosinophils. Immunofluorescence findings were negative. CT scans revealed 2 masses in the pancreas. What is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of cohort study?

options.label: B

A 34-year-old man comes to the clinic due to severe fatigue. The patient was diagnosed with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria 3 years ago, and he has required several blood transfusions due to anemia. Treatment is initiated with a monoclonal antibody that prevents formation of the protein complex leading to hemolysis in this patient. Prophylactic pharmacotherapy will be required to prevent infection by which of the following organisms?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD due to skin lesions on his chin for the past 2 days. Temperature is 36.10 C. The patient is well-appearing. There are mildly tender perioral papules and pustules, some of which appear to have broken down and are covered with amber-colored crusting. A wound culture is taken, and Gram stain shows gram-positive cocci in chains. Choose the presumptive test to confirm the pathogen.

An epidemiologic study is conducted after a sudden increase in the rate of severe postoperative infections in a rural hospital. It is determined that all the patients who developed the infection were operated on with surgical instruments sterilized by a specific autoclave machine. The machine was found to be inadequately sterilizing the equipment due to a malfunction limiting the temperature to 1000 C during the 15-minute cycle. These patients most likely developed infection from which of the following bacteria?

A 43-year-old man undergoes induction chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia. Three weeks later, he is hospitalized with fever, cough, and generalized weakness. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.1 deg C, blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg, and pulse is 125/min. The patient's pulse oximetry shows 95% on room air. Crackles are heard over the right upper lung. His hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 900/mm3 with an absolute neutrophil count of 100/mm3. Chest x-ray reveals a dense infiltrate involving the right upper lung lobe. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is instituted. Five days later, the patient is still febrile. Bronchoscopy with biopsy is performed and microscopy shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
